ratings.comment: This teacher single handedly convinced me to drop Philosophy as my second minor. He is more concerned with phone use and students reading newspapers than how many kids actually show up to his classes. Nothing he says sees to "explain" ever makes any sense, and he fails to recognize the lack of meaning anything he "teaches" has.
It's a great class, and he really knows what he's talking about. He is easy to follow, and the tests are extremely easy.

Good professor, but even though lectures were interesting it was hard to stay awake. Maybe it was the way he spoke in a gentle Spanish accent as he paced across the front of the class, soothing me to sleep. I went to lecture consistently in the beginning of the semester and stopped going, mostly because of the review sessions before every exam.

Only take this class if you're interested in philosophy.  I thought I was but I was completely wrong.  Juan is a nice guy, I just nearly fell asleep in every lecture.  He gives the exam essays before the test which is really nice but the material itself is so boring.
Lectures are very hard to follow, and if you don't have an interest in philosophy to begin with - expect to get lost, or fall asleep. However, if you luck out with a good TA you'll make it through.

Juan really is a genious.  His accent makes his lectures more interesting and captivating.  I have fallen in love with philosophy thanks to this class.  I HIGHLY recomend this professor to anyone interested in philosophy.  The class isn't that hard either.
Unlike other raters, I thought he was a very clear lecturer.  I was actually surprised at how structured his lectures were despite the fact that he didn't use notes.  Nice guy, too.

I liked Juan. Lectures were interesting and very clear. He sometimes rambled off topic, but it was still interesting and you could tell he really likes what he teaches and knows A LOT about it. Readings were good, sometimes hard to get through, but he usually went through everything you need to know in lecture. Exams were fine.
This guy knows his stuff. If you keep up with the reading and take good notes, you should do well in this class.

Juan is one of the best lecturers i've had here at Madison.  He explains things well, the trick is you have to pay attention. His exams are fair, readings are short (and not entirely necessary). i highly recommend him.

Juan is hot. He rambles on a lot about his slides, but none of that is on the tests. The tests consist of a short answer section and an essay portion. He gives you all of the essay questions a week in advance, so that's very helpful. He HATES laptops and doesn't allow you to take notes on them.
He's pretty good. Keeps lectures interesting.
Might as well have been singing lullabies.  Hes the anti-red bull.

sooo much to remember for the exams. hope to get a good TA if you have Juan cuz he doesn't explain things too well, he kind of just expects that you understand everything. DONT BOTHER DOING ANY OF THE READINGS! He covers every reading in the lectures; you don't even need to buy the book.

Juan is an awesome professor. Very young, but really knows what he's talking about (it helps, though, if you have a good TA of course, philosophy can be tough). Also, it doesn't hurt that he's pretty hot and has a sexy accent ;)
hes hot. eye candy. thats about it. classes were boring. good topics but he rambles. a lot.

it's easy to teach 101, teaching a higher level course proves the true worth of a professor. he was a rambler, hard to keep up with, never began discussions, ever knew what to take notes on. so boring tat even coming to class was a difficult decision.
hated the class

If you pay attention in lecture and take notes... he's a good teacher. It's a hard class, but philosophy is a hard subject to begin with. There are a lot of concepts to remember over the semster, though if you get stuck on something ASK FOR HELP and he will gladly attent to your needs.

Interesting topics, but very unstructured lectures.  Hard to follow and take notes.  If you have a good, organized, clear TA your alright.  The tests aren't too bad, but you need to be very familiar with topics/concepts.

For a philosphy professor, he is pretty good.  Everything on the tests is in lecture.  The tests are easy.  If you are interested in philosophy, the class is great too, many interesting topics covered and covered quite clearly.
boring
Not very atriculate in lecture.  Rambles on about topics, makes taking notes difficult because you never know what to write down.  Just hope you get a good TA if you have Juan.
